title: Introduction to Stoicism
summary: This text introduces Stoicism, a philosophy founded by Zeno of Cyprus, emphasizing virtue, tolerance, self-control, and living in accordance with nature. It explores the core tenets of Stoicism, including the concept of Logos, the four cardinal virtues (Practical wisdom, Temperance, Justice, and Courage), and its focus on personal improvement as a means to positive change. The text also discusses influential Stoics like Seneca, Marcus Aurelius, and Epictetus, and the continuing relevance of Stoicism in modern psychology and self-help movements.

concepts.name: Stoicism
concepts.description: A philosophy originated by Zeno of Cyprus that emphasizes virtue, tolerance, and self-control as paths to happiness and fulfillment. It focuses on accepting what we cannot control and directing our energy towards what we can, aiming for inner peace and resilience.

concepts.name: Logos
concepts.description: The Stoic concept of a rational structure of the universe, representing the interconnected web of cause and effect that governs all events.

concepts.name: Virtue
concepts.description: The cornerstone of Stoic ethics, encompassing qualities like practical wisdom, temperance, justice, and courage. Stoics strive to cultivate these virtues to live a fulfilling and meaningful life.

concepts.name: Self-Control
concepts.description: The ability to manage one's emotions, desires, and impulses.  A key aspect of Stoicism that enables individuals to respond rationally and virtuously to life's challenges.

notes.heading: Zeno's Journey to Stoicism
bullets: Zeno of Cyprus lost his wealth in a shipwreck near Athens.
He became interested in philosophy after reading about Socrates in a bookshop.
He studied with philosophers in Athens and eventually founded Stoicism.

notes.heading: Core Tenets of Stoicism
bullets: Stoicism emphasizes virtue, tolerance, and self-control.
The name Stoicism comes from the Stoa Poikile, a public colonnade where Zeno taught.
Stoicism involves accepting what we cannot control and focusing on what we can.
The Stoics believed in a rational structure of the universe called Logos.
The four cardinal virtues are: Practical wisdom, Temperance, Justice, and Courage.

notes.heading: Stoicism in Practice and History
bullets: Stoicism focuses on personal improvement but is not self-centered.
Seneca advocated for the humane treatment of slaves.
Marcus Aurelius used Stoicism to lead the Roman Empire through wars and personal loss.
Nelson Mandela found guidance and comfort in Marcus Aurelius' journals during his imprisonment.
Epictetus believed that suffering stems from our judgments about events, not the events themselves.

notes.heading: Modern Applications of Stoicism
bullets: Stoicism has influenced Christian theologians and shares parallels with Buddhist concepts like Nirvana.
Rational emotive behavioral therapy (REBT) is influenced by Stoic principles.
Viktor Frankl's logotherapy is based on the Stoic principle of finding meaning in life, even in difficult circumstances.
